summary: This document is an Agreed Protective Order filed in the civil case against Ghislaine Maxwell (Case No. 15-cv-07433). It establishes rules for handling confidential information, particularly sensitive personal information relating to victims of sexual abuse, during the discovery process. The order was transmitted between attorneys for the parties.

persons.name: Laura Menninger
persons.context: Recipient of the facsimile transmission containing the Agreed Protective Order. She is an attorney at Haddon, Morgan and Foreman, P.C.

persons.name: Sigrid S. McCawley
persons.context: Sender of the facsimile transmission and the accompanying Agreed Protective Order. She is an attorney at Boies, Schiller & Flexner LLP.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Named as the defendant in the civil case (15-cv-07433). The protective order is designed to protect confidential information, including information relating to her and victims of sexual abuse.

connections.description: Attorneys on opposing sides of the case, communicating to exchange legal documents (the Agreed Protective Order).
Implied relationship as McCawley is transmitting an order concerning the defendant Maxwell; she is likely representing the plaintiff in the case.
Implied relationship as Menninger is receiving the order on behalf of the defendant Maxwell; she is likely part of Maxwell's defense team.

events.title: Transmission of Agreed Protective Order
events.description: Attorney Sigrid S. McCawley transmits a facsimile to Attorney Laura Menninger containing an Agreed Protective Order for the case against Ghislaine Maxwell.

keyFacts: The document is a court-ordered Agreed Protective Order designed to safeguard confidential information in the civil case against Ghislaine Maxwell.
The order specifically aims to protect sensitive personal information relating to victims of sexual abuse, as well as information pertaining to defendant Ghislaine Maxwell.
Confidential information under this order can be disclosed to law enforcement for investigation purposes.
The order outlines strict procedures for designating, challenging, and ultimately returning or destroying confidential materials after the case concludes.
The transmission indicates active legal proceedings and discovery in the civil case (15-cv-07433) as of February 2016.
